title: Acts Chapter 25 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 25 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 25 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 25.

questions.question: Who came into the province and ascended from Caesarea to Jerusalem after three days?
questions.correctAnswer: Festus
questions.explanation: Acts 25:1 states that Festus came into the province and after three days ascended from Caesarea to Jerusalem.

questions.question: Who informed Festus against Paul and desired favor against him?
options: The high priest and the chief of the Jews
The chief captains of the city
questions.correctAnswer: The high priest and the chief of the Jews
questions.explanation: Acts 25:2 says the high priest and the chief of the Jews informed Festus against Paul and sought favor.

questions.question: Where did Festus decide Paul should be kept?
questions.correctAnswer: Caesarea
questions.explanation: Acts 25:4 states Festus answered that Paul should be kept at Caesarea.

questions.question: How long did Festus stay among the Jews before going down to Caesarea?
questions.correctAnswer: More than ten days
questions.explanation: Acts 25:6 says Festus tarried among them more than ten days before he went down to Caesarea.

questions.question: What did Paul say about his offenses when he answered the complaints against him?
options: He had offended neither the law of the Jews, nor the temple, nor Caesar
He had broken the law of the Romans
He was guilty of temple crimes
He admitted to offenses against Caesar
questions.correctAnswer: He had offended neither the law of the Jews, nor the temple, nor Caesar
questions.explanation: Acts 25:8 records Paul’s response that he had offended nothing against the law, the temple, or Caesar.

questions.question: What did Festus ask Paul about going to Jerusalem for judgment?
options: Wilt thou go up to Jerusalem, and there be judged of these things before me?
Do you want to be sent to Caesar immediately?
Are you guilty of crimes in Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Wilt thou go up to Jerusalem, and there be judged of these things before me?
questions.explanation: Acts 25:9 shows Festus asking Paul if he would go to Jerusalem to be judged there.

questions.question: To whom did Paul say he appealed for judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Caesar
questions.explanation: Acts 25:11 states Paul appealed unto Caesar for judgment.

questions.question: What was Festus's response after conferring with the council about Paul's appeal?
questions.correctAnswer: Unto Caesar shalt thou go
questions.explanation: Acts 25:12 records Festus's decision to send Paul to Caesar after his appeal.

questions.question: Who came to Caesarea to salute Festus?
questions.correctAnswer: King Agrippa and Bernice
questions.explanation: Acts 25:13 mentions King Agrippa and Bernice coming to Caesarea to salute Festus.

questions.question: What reason did Festus give for not sending Paul to die without a trial?
options: It is not the manner of the Romans to deliver any man to die before he has accusers face to face
There was no proof against Paul
questions.correctAnswer: It is not the manner of the Romans to deliver any man to die before he has accusers face to face
questions.explanation: Acts 25:16 explains Festus’s reply regarding Roman legal customs about trials.

questions.question: True or False: The Jews brought many accusations against Paul that they could prove.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 25:7 states that the Jews laid many grievous complaints against Paul which they could not prove.

questions.question: True or False: Paul refused to appeal to Caesar and accepted judgment by Festus alone.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 25:11 shows Paul appealing to Caesar, refusing to be judged only by Festus.

questions.question: True or False: King Agrippa expressed a desire to hear Paul's case himself.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 25:22 records Agrippa saying he would also hear the man himself.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Acts 25:18: 'Against whom when the accusers stood up, they brought none accusation of such things as I supposed: But had certain questions against him of their own ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: superstition
questions.explanation: Acts 25:18 states the accusers had questions based on their own superstition.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Acts 25:27: 'For it seemeth to me unreasonable to send a prisoner, and not withal to signify the ______ laid against him.'
questions.correctAnswer: crimes
questions.explanation: Acts 25:27 expresses Festus’s opinion that it is unreasonable to send a prisoner without specifying the crimes laid against him.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 25 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 25 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is facing false accusations and asks how to respond with integrity. Based on Acts 25, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Trust God and confidently defend your innocence with truth
Avoid all confrontation and remain silent
Falsify evidence to prove your point
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God and confidently defend your innocence with truth
questions.explanation: Paul answered for himself that he had not offended any law, showing integrity and trust in God's justice (Acts 25:7-8, 25:19-20, 25:24).

questions.question: How does Acts 25 teach us about perseverance through trials when Paul appeals to Caesar?
options: We should stand firm in our faith and seek God's protection through proper channels
We should give up and accept unjust treatment
We should hide from our problems
questions.correctAnswer: We should stand firm in our faith and seek God's protection through proper channels
questions.explanation: Paul appeals to Caesar to ensure a fair hearing, showing perseverance and trust in God's sovereign plan (Acts 25:10-12, 25:21, 25:26-27).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise integrity at work. What insight from Acts 25 encourages honesty and integrity?
options: Paul maintained his innocence and refused to admit guilt without evidence
Paul accepted false accusations to avoid trouble
Paul used deceit to escape imprisonment
questions.correctAnswer: Paul maintained his innocence and refused to admit guilt without evidence
questions.explanation: Paul confidently declared he had committed no offense against Jewish law, the Temple, or Caesar, emphasizing honesty and integrity (Acts 25:8, 25:18, 25:24).

questions.question: How does Acts 25 encourage believers to trust in God's timing during difficult circumstances?
options: Festus waited over ten days before acting on Paul's case
questions.correctAnswer: Festus waited over ten days before acting on Paul's case
questions.explanation: The delay before judgment shows patience and trust in God's timing rather than rushing to conclusions (Acts 25:6, 25:17, 25:21).

questions.question: In Acts 25, what lesson about humility can we learn from Paul’s appeal to Caesar?
options: Paul humbly accepted the authority of Caesar for judgment
Paul arrogantly refused any earthly authority
Paul declared himself above all judges
questions.correctAnswer: Paul humbly accepted the authority of Caesar for judgment
questions.explanation: Paul recognized the proper authority and appealed to Caesar, showing humility in respecting lawful authority (Acts 25:10-12, 25:26).

questions.question: A believer wants to share the gospel under opposition. What example from Acts 25 can encourage bold witness?
options: Paul boldly affirmed Jesus was alive despite opposition
Paul denied his faith to avoid trouble
questions.correctAnswer: Paul boldly affirmed Jesus was alive despite opposition
questions.explanation: The accusers focused on Jesus, whom Paul declared alive, demonstrating boldness in witnessing even when challenged (Acts 25:19).

questions.question: How does Acts 25 teach the importance of prayer and spiritual discipline in trials?
options: Paul remained composed and respectful, implying reliance on God’s strength
Paul gave in to anger and despair
Paul tried to solve his problems alone
questions.correctAnswer: Paul remained composed and respectful, implying reliance on God’s strength
questions.explanation: Paul’s calm and respectful demeanor before Festus and Agrippa suggests a life rooted in prayer and spiritual discipline (Acts 25:6-10, 25:23-24).

questions.question: True or False: Festus immediately sent Paul to Jerusalem to be judged before hearing the accusations.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Festus kept Paul at Caesarea and waited to hear the accusations and Paul's defense before deciding (Acts 25:4-6, 25:14-17).

questions.question: True or False: Paul appealed to Caesar only because he was guilty and wanted to delay justice.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Paul appealed to Caesar because he had done no wrong and sought a fair trial, not to delay justice (Acts 25:10-12, 25:11).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Festus told King Agrippa he had no certain thing to write unto his lord about Paul because _______.
options: the accusations were unproven and unreasonable
Paul was found guilty of treason
questions.correctAnswer: the accusations were unproven and unreasonable
questions.explanation: Festus explained he found no worthy charge against Paul to justify his death or to report to Caesar (Acts 25:18-19, 25:26-27).

questions.question: How does Acts 25 illustrate the value of seeking counsel and wise leadership in difficult decisions?
options: Festus conferred with the council before answering Paul
Agrippa refused to hear the case
questions.correctAnswer: Festus conferred with the council before answering Paul
questions.explanation: Festus involved the council before giving decisions, showing the importance of wise counsel (Acts 25:12, 25:17).

questions.question: A believer struggles with bitterness toward accusers. What teaching from Acts 25 can help them respond with love and forgiveness?
options: Paul answered respectfully and appealed to justice without bitterness
Paul spoke harshly to his accusers
questions.correctAnswer: Paul answered respectfully and appealed to justice without bitterness
questions.explanation: Paul maintained respectful speech and trusted God’s justice rather than bitterness (Acts 25:8-11, 25:24).

questions.question: How does Acts 25 show the importance of standing firm in faith even when facing legal trials?
options: Paul did not deny his faith and openly affirmed Jesus’ resurrection
Paul renounced his faith to avoid punishment
Paul remained silent about his beliefs
questions.correctAnswer: Paul did not deny his faith and openly affirmed Jesus’ resurrection
questions.explanation: Paul boldly spoke of Jesus alive despite opposition, demonstrating steadfast faith (Acts 25:19-20).

questions.question: How does Acts 25 teach about contentment and trust during uncertain circumstances?
options: Paul accepted imprisonment calmly, trusting God’s plan
Paul complained loudly and lost hope
questions.correctAnswer: Paul accepted imprisonment calmly, trusting God’s plan
questions.explanation: Paul’s composed attitude in prison indicates contentment and trust in God’s sovereign will (Acts 25:4-6, 25:21).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because of court-like opposition. Based on Acts 25, what biblical principle can encourage them?
options: God honors those who stand firm and appeal to truth and justice
It is best to give up and avoid conflict
Silence is always the best defense
questions.correctAnswer: God honors those who stand firm and appeal to truth and justice
questions.explanation: Paul stood firm in truth and appealed justly, demonstrating reliance on God's justice (Acts 25:8-12, 25:25-27).

hard.title: Acts Chapter 25 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 25.

questions.question: Who was the Roman official that came into the province and ascended from Caesarea to Jerusalem after three days?
questions.correctAnswer: Festus
questions.explanation: Acts 25:1 states that Festus came into the province and ascended from Caesarea to Jerusalem after three days.

questions.question: What was the primary accusation of the high priest and chief of the Jews against Paul when they informed Festus?
options: They requested Paul be sent to Jerusalem to face charges and laid wait to kill him
They accused Paul of blasphemy against the temple
They claimed Paul had stolen from the temple treasury
They said Paul was inciting rebellion against Caesar
questions.correctAnswer: They requested Paul be sent to Jerusalem to face charges and laid wait to kill him
questions.explanation: Acts 25:3 shows the Jews desired Festus to send Paul to Jerusalem and planned to kill him en route.

questions.question: How did Festus respond to the request that Paul be sent to Jerusalem?
options: He decided Paul should be kept at Caesarea and that he himself would soon go there
He immediately sent Paul to Jerusalem
He ordered Paul to be released
He handed Paul over to the Jewish leaders
questions.correctAnswer: He decided Paul should be kept at Caesarea and that he himself would soon go there
questions.explanation: Acts 25:4 records Festus’s answer that Paul should remain at Caesarea and that Festus would depart shortly to Caesarea.

questions.question: True or False: Festus invited the accusers to go with him to Caesarea to present any charges against Paul.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 25:5 shows Festus invited those able to accuse Paul to accompany him and present their charges in Caesarea.

questions.question: What was Paul's defense when the Jews laid many grievous complaints against him in Caesarea?
options: He had offended neither the Jewish law, the temple, nor Caesar
He admitted to minor offenses but denied major charges
He said he was innocent because he was a Roman citizen
He claimed he was not present at the events
questions.correctAnswer: He had offended neither the Jewish law, the temple, nor Caesar
questions.explanation: Acts 25:8 quotes Paul defending himself by saying he had not offended the law of the Jews, the temple, nor Caesar.

questions.question: What was Festus’s suggestion to Paul regarding his trial?
options: To go to Jerusalem and be judged there
To be sent to Caesar without trial
To be tried privately without accusers
questions.correctAnswer: To go to Jerusalem and be judged there
questions.explanation: Acts 25:9 records Festus asking Paul if he wished to go to Jerusalem to be judged there.

questions.question: Paul appealed to Caesar because, according to him, where ought he to be judged?
questions.correctAnswer: At Caesar's judgment seat
questions.explanation: Acts 25:10–11 shows Paul stating he stands at Caesar's judgment seat and appeals to Caesar for trial.

questions.question: What reason did Festus give for sending Paul to Caesar?
options: Paul had appealed to Caesar after Festus conferred with the council
Paul was accused of a crime punishable by death
Paul requested to be sent to Caesar for protection
Festus was ordered by the emperor to send him
questions.correctAnswer: Paul had appealed to Caesar after Festus conferred with the council
questions.explanation: Acts 25:12 states that after conferring with his council, Festus acknowledged Paul's appeal to Caesar and decided to send him.

questions.question: Who came to Caesarea to salute Festus, creating an opportunity for Festus to discuss Paul's case?
questions.correctAnswer: King Agrippa and Bernice
questions.explanation: Acts 25:13 mentions that King Agrippa and Bernice came to Caesarea to salute Festus.

questions.question: What was Festus’s observation about the accusations against Paul brought by the Jews?
options: The accusations were not of crimes Festus expected and involved questions about Jewish superstition and Jesus
They were serious crimes of sedition against Rome
They were based on Paul's Roman citizenship
questions.correctAnswer: The accusations were not of crimes Festus expected and involved questions about Jewish superstition and Jesus
questions.explanation: Acts 25:18–19 shows Festus noting the accusers brought no charges of expected crimes but questioned Paul about their superstition and Jesus whom Paul claimed was alive.

questions.question: Why did Festus hesitate to proceed with the questions against Paul?
options: Because he doubted the nature of the questions and asked Paul if he wanted to go to Jerusalem
Because Paul was a Roman citizen
Because he wanted to consult the emperor first
questions.correctAnswer: Because he doubted the nature of the questions and asked Paul if he wanted to go to Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Acts 25:20 explains Festus's doubt about the questions and his proposal for Paul to be judged in Jerusalem.

questions.question: What was King Agrippa's reaction to Paul's case?
options: He expressed a desire to hear Paul himself
He dismissed the case as insignificant
He insisted on Paul's immediate execution
questions.correctAnswer: He expressed a desire to hear Paul himself
questions.explanation: Acts 25:22 quotes Agrippa saying he would like to hear the man himself.

questions.question: How did Festus describe the Jewish accusations against Paul before King Agrippa and others?
options: They claimed Paul deserved to die, but Festus found no fault worthy of death
They accused Paul of treason against Rome
They said Paul had committed theft
They charged Paul with blasphemy and heresy
questions.correctAnswer: They claimed Paul deserved to die, but Festus found no fault worthy of death
questions.explanation: Acts 25:24–25 shows Festus stating Jews cried that Paul should not live, but Festus found no crime worthy of death.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Festus said it seemed unreasonable to send a prisoner without __________.
options: signifying the crimes laid against him
questions.correctAnswer: signifying the crimes laid against him
questions.explanation: Acts 25:27 shows Festus felt it unreasonable to send a prisoner without specifying the crimes against him.

questions.question: What is the significance of Paul's appeal to Caesar in the context of Roman law and his Roman citizenship?
options: It reflects Paul's right as a Roman citizen to be tried before the emperor, ensuring legal protection
It was a way to delay the trial indefinitely
It was a customary appeal made by all accused Jews
It was a political move to gain favor among Roman leaders
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects Paul's right as a Roman citizen to be tried before the emperor, ensuring legal protection
questions.explanation: Acts 25:10–12 demonstrates Paul's use of his Roman citizenship to appeal to Caesar, a legal right ensuring he would not be unjustly tried by local authorities.

theological.title: Acts Chapter 25 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 25 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the initial request of the high priest and chief of the Jews to Festus regarding Paul?
options: That Festus send Paul to Jerusalem where they planned to kill him
That Paul be sent to Caesar without trial
That Paul be executed in Caesarea
questions.correctAnswer: That Festus send Paul to Jerusalem where they planned to kill him
questions.explanation: Acts 25:2-3 records that the high priest and chief Jews informed Festus against Paul and desired him to send Paul to Jerusalem, laying wait to kill him. This reflects human hostility and injustice against Paul, echoing the suffering of God's servants throughout Scripture (e.g., Psalm 37:12-13, John 15:20, 2 Timothy 3:12).

questions.question: How did Festus respond to the request to send Paul to Jerusalem?
options: He decided Paul should remain in Caesarea and he himself would go there soon
He immediately sent Paul to Jerusalem
He sent Paul to Caesar directly
questions.correctAnswer: He decided Paul should remain in Caesarea and he himself would go there soon
questions.explanation: Acts 25:4 shows Festus's answer that Paul should be kept in Caesarea and that he would depart there shortly. This illustrates the Roman legal principle of local jurisdiction and the protection of a prisoner from unlawful plots, consistent with Roman justice (Acts 25:16) and God’s providential care (Psalm 34:19).

questions.question: What challenge did Festus give to the accusers of Paul?
options: Let those who can accuse Paul of wickedness come with him to Caesarea
They must present their case before Caesar
They should release Paul if no proof is found
questions.correctAnswer: Let those who can accuse Paul of wickedness come with him to Caesarea
questions.explanation: Festus invited those able to accuse Paul to accompany him to Caesarea to present their case (Acts 25:5). This reflects the biblical principle of fair trial and evidence (Deuteronomy 19:15, Proverbs 18:17), underscoring God's justice and human accountability.

questions.question: In his defense, what did Paul claim regarding the accusations against him?
options: He had not offended the Jewish law, the temple, or Caesar
He confessed to breaking the law of the Jews
He refused to answer any charges
questions.correctAnswer: He had not offended the Jewish law, the temple, or Caesar
questions.explanation: Paul stated in Acts 25:8 that he had committed no offense against Jewish law, the temple, or Caesar. This defense aligns with the biblical portrayal of the righteous suffering unjustly (1 Peter 2:19-21), affirming Paul’s innocence and the truth of the gospel he preached (Acts 24:16).

questions.question: Why did Paul appeal to Caesar?
options: To receive a fair trial as a Roman citizen before the highest authority
To be sent to Jerusalem for trial
To avoid any trial or hearing
questions.correctAnswer: To receive a fair trial as a Roman citizen before the highest authority
questions.explanation: Paul appealed to Caesar, asserting his right as a Roman citizen to be judged by the emperor (Acts 25:10-11). This appeal exemplifies the biblical affirmation of lawful authority (Romans 13:1-7) and the protection of the innocent, reflecting God’s justice and sovereignty over earthly powers (Daniel 2:21).

questions.question: What was Festus's verdict after consulting with his council regarding Paul's appeal?
options: Paul would be sent to Caesar as he had appealed
Paul would be tried in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Paul would be sent to Caesar as he had appealed
questions.explanation: Festus, after consulting his council, declared that since Paul had appealed to Caesar, he must be sent to Caesar (Acts 25:12). This respects legal due process and the Roman principle of appeals, highlighting God’s providential ordering of events (Proverbs 21:1).

questions.question: What reason did Festus give for why he could not write a clear report to Caesar about Paul?
options: He found no certain crimes to report against Paul
He was biased and refused to write
Paul had confessed to crimes but Festus was unsure
The Jews refused to provide any accusations
questions.correctAnswer: He found no certain crimes to report against Paul
questions.explanation: Festus stated in Acts 25:26-27 that he had no certain things to write to Caesar about Paul and that it seemed unreasonable to send a prisoner without specifying the crimes. This reflects the biblical principle of clear accusations before judgment (Deuteronomy 19:15), emphasizing God’s justice and truthfulness.

questions.question: What unusual accusations did the Jews bring against Paul according to Festus?
options: Questions about their own superstition and about Jesus who Paul said was alive
questions.correctAnswer: Questions about their own superstition and about Jesus who Paul said was alive
questions.explanation: Acts 25:19 describes that the accusations related to Jewish superstition and Jesus, whom Paul claimed to be alive despite being dead. This highlights early Christian claims concerning Christ's resurrection, central to Christian doctrine (1 Corinthians 15:3-8), and addresses objections to the gospel's veracity.

questions.question: How did Festus describe the manner of Roman law regarding delivering a man to die?
options: Romans do not deliver a man to die before he has accusers face to face and a chance to answer
Romans always execute accused without trial
Romans do not allow anyone to appeal to Caesar
questions.correctAnswer: Romans do not deliver a man to die before he has accusers face to face and a chance to answer
questions.explanation: Festus explained in Acts 25:16 that Roman custom forbids execution without the accused confronting his accusers and having the right to defend himself. This underscores the biblical theme of justice and fairness (Exodus 23:1-3), reflecting God's attribute of righteousness.

questions.question: Who came to Caesarea to visit Festus and hear Paul's case?
questions.correctAnswer: King Agrippa and Bernice
questions.explanation: Acts 25:13 mentions that King Agrippa and Bernice came to Caesarea to salute Festus, later hearing Paul's defense. This illustrates how Paul's case was of political and religious significance, integrating the gospel into the unfolding historical and political narrative of Scripture (Acts 9:15).

questions.question: What was Festus's attitude toward the accusations against Paul when he sat on the judgment seat?
options: He found no credible accusations matching the charges
He was indifferent and refused to judge
questions.correctAnswer: He found no credible accusations matching the charges
questions.explanation: Acts 25:18 shows that Festus observed the accusers brought no charges matching the expected crimes. This reflects the biblical principle that false accusations are condemned (Exodus 23:1), affirming God’s justice and the innocence of Paul.

questions.question: What did Agrippa express a desire to do regarding Paul's case?
options: Execute Paul to please the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: Hear the man himself
questions.explanation: Acts 25:22 records Agrippa's wish to hear Paul personally. This reflects the biblical importance of hearing all sides before judgment (Proverbs 18:13), and God's providence in advancing the gospel through trials (Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What was the setting when Paul was brought forth before King Agrippa and Bernice?
options: In a place of hearing with chief captains and principal men present
In a private chamber with only Festus present
questions.correctAnswer: In a place of hearing with chief captains and principal men present
questions.explanation: Acts 25:23 describes Paul being brought before Agrippa and Bernice with chief captains and principal men present, indicating a formal judicial hearing. This setting underscores the public nature of Paul's defense and the providential spread of the gospel before rulers (Psalm 2:2-4).

questions.question: How did Festus describe the Jewish accusations against Paul before King Agrippa?
options: They cried that Paul should no longer live
questions.correctAnswer: They cried that Paul should no longer live
questions.explanation: Acts 25:24 records Festus stating the Jews cried out that Paul should not live any longer, revealing their intense opposition and the cost of faithful witness. This echoes Old Testament themes of persecution of the righteous (Psalm 109:3-5) and Christ's own experience (Luke 23:18).

questions.question: What was the ultimate legal outcome determined by Festus for Paul?
options: To send Paul to Caesar for judgment
To hand Paul over to the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: To send Paul to Caesar for judgment
questions.explanation: Festus decided to send Paul to Caesar (Acts 25:25), respecting Paul's appeal and Roman law. This reveals God's sovereignty over political authorities and the unfolding salvation history (Daniel 4:17, Romans 13:1).
